elements.content: Six lanthanide coordination polymers of the formula [Ln(L1)0.5(H2O)2]·2H2O [where Ln3+: Eu3+ (1), Tb3+ (2), and Gd3+(3)] and [Me2NH2][Ln(H2L2)(H2O)4]·0.5DMF·xH2O [where Ln3+: Eu3+ (4), Tb3+ (5), and Gd3+(6)], based on p-terphenyl-2,2″,2‴,5,5″,5‴-hexacarboxylate acid (H6L1), and p-terphenyl-3,2″,3″,5,5″,5‴,-hexacarboxylate acid (H6L2), have been solvothermally synthesized and structurally characterized. Complexes 1–3 are 3D frameworks exhibiting 6-connected pcu alpha-Po primitive cubic network with topology (412.63), while complexes 4–6 show two-dimensional (2D) architectures showing simplified 3,4-connected binodal net and (4.62)(42.62.82) topology. Detailed photophysical behaviors have been explored on Eu3+, Tb3+, and Gd3+ complexes. The calculated triplet state energies of H6L1 and H6L2 lie above the emissive levels of Eu3+ or Tb3+ in an ideal range for sensitizing. Furthermore, it is demonstrated that the optimum energy gap between the triplet state of ligand H6L1 and the emissive level of Tb3+ ion makes the overall quantum yield of Tb3+ complex (2) larger than its corresponding Eu3+ complex (1). In addition, the coordinated water in the inner sphere has a significant negative influence on the overall quantum yield, especially for the Eu3+ complex (4) compared to the Tb3+ complex (5), due to the deactivation process caused by vibrational OH oscillators.

elements.content: Lanthanide coordination polymers have attracted extensive attention due to their fascinating luminescent properties, which render their use for extensive applications, such as in light-emitting materials, bioanalytical sensors, and optical communications, etc. Especially europium and terbium complexes are considered to be promising luminescent materials because of the strong luminescent electronically excited states and high monochromatic clear emissions. However, the emissions of the 4f–4f transitions are forbidden by parity (Laporte) selection rules, which make the direct excitation of lanthanide disfavored and the absorption coefficients small. However, such weak absorption can be overcome when the organic ligand is introduced to function as an antenna which sensitizes the luminescence of lanthanide by energy transfer from the ligand to lanthanide ion. Such a process, founded by Weissman, is thereafter called antenna effect. Therefore, a ligand possessing high triplet state energy as well as large absorption across the section is necessary in order to obtain the lanthanide complexes with excellent luminescent properties. In this regard, a wide array of ligands such as β-diketonate and aromatic carboxylate have drawn the most attention. Though many lanthanide coordination complexes, as well as those based on polycarboxylate ligands, have been reported on the syntheses, structures, and photophysical properties; reports based on terphenyl hexacarboxylate ligands remain far less studied.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Lanthanide coordination polymers have attracted extensive attention due to their fascinating luminescent properties, which render their use for extensive applications, such as in light-emitting materials, bioanalytical sensors, and optical communications, etc. Especially europium and terbium complexes are considered to be promising luminescent materials because of the strong luminescent electronically excited states and high monochromatic clear emissions. However, the emissions of the 4f-4f transitions are forbidden by parity (Laporte) selection rules, which make the direct excitation of lanthanide disfavored and the absorption coefficients small. However, such weak absorption can be overcome when the organic ligand is introduced to function as an antenna which sensitizes the luminescence of lanthanide by energy transfer from the ligand to lanthanide ion. Such a process, founded by Weissman, is thereafter called antenna effect. Therefore, a ligand possessing high triplet state energy as well as large absorption across the section is necessary in order to obtain the lanthanide complexes with excellent luminescent properties. In this regard, a wide array of ligands such as β-diketonate and aromatic carboxylate have drawn the most attention. Though many lanthanide coordination complexes, as well as those based on polycarboxylate ligands, have been reported on the syntheses, structures, and photophysical properties; reports based on terphenyl hexacarboxylate ligands remain far less studied.

elements.content: Very recently, we have reported some work on three europium coordination polymers based on the p-terphenyl-3,3″,5,5″-tetracarboxylic ligand, demonstrating that such a ligand has the capability of sensitizing europium luminescence. Inspired by the efficient sensitization, we have now employed two new terphenyl hexacarboxylate ligands, namely p-terphenyl-2,2″,2‴,5,5″,5‴-hexacarboxylate acid (H6L1) and p-terphenyl-3,2″,3″,5,5″,5‴-hexacarboxylate acid (H6L2), to further explore the influence of the triplet state of ligands and the emissive state of lanthanide ions as well as the water molecules in such lanthanide complex systems. In this paper, syntheses and structures of these coordination polymers, [Ln(L1)0.5(H2O)2]·2H2O [where Ln3+: Eu3+ (1), Tb3+ (2), Gd3+ (3)] and [Me2NH2] [Ln(H2L2)(H2O)4]·0.5DMF·xH2O [where Ln3+: Eu3+ (4), Tb3+ (5), Gd3+ (6)], have been described. The luminescence properties involve the lifetimes, quantum yields, radiative and nonradiative rates, and sensitization efficiencies have been further studied.

Inspired by the efficient sensitization, we have now employed two new terphenyl hexacarboxylate ligands, namely p-terphenyl-2,2",2‴,5,5",5‴-hexacarboxylate acid (H6L1) and p-terphenyl-3,2",3",5,5",5‴-hexacarboxylate acid (H6L2), to further explore the influence of the triplet state of ligands and the emissive state of lanthanide ions as well as the water molecules in such lanthanide complex systems. In this paper, syntheses and structures of these coordination polymers, [Ln(L1)0.5(H2O)2]⋅2H2O [where Ln3+: Eu3+ (1), Tb3+ (2), Gd3+ (3)] and [Me2NH2] [Ln(H2L2)(H2O)4]⋅0.5DMF⋅xH2O [where Ln3+: Eu3+ (4), Tb3+ (5), Gd3+ (6)], have been described. The luminescence properties involve the lifetimes, quantum yields, radiative and nonradiative rates, and sensitization efficiencies have been further studied.

elements.content: The reagents and solvents were commercially available and used as received. The elemental analyses were carried out on an Elementar Vario MICRO elemental analyzer. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was performed on a Cu Kα radiation equipped RIGAKU-DMAX 2500 diffractometer. The IR spectra were collected from KBr pellets on a PerkinElmer Spectrum One FT-IR spectrometer in the range of 4000–400 cm–1. The thermogravimetry and thermogravimetry mass spectrometric diagrams were collected during 30–1000 °C on a Netzsch STA 449C instrument, which is equipped with mass spectrometry Blazers MID for the thermogravimetry-mass spectrometric analyses. The emission and excitation spectra were collected using a Fluorolog-3 spectrophotometer from Horiba Jobin Yvon. The overall quantum yields were measured based on the previously reported technique, and the lifetimes were obtained on an Edinburgh FLS920 spectrofluorometer in the solid state. The diffuse reflectance spectra were recorded on an integrating sphere equipped Lambda-900 spectrophotometer from PerkinElmer company, with BaSO4 used as a reference.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Apparatus

The reagents and solvents were commercially available and used as received. The elemental analyses were carried out on an Elementar Vario MICRO elemental analyzer. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was performed on a Cu Kα radiation equipped RIGAKU-DMAX 2500 diffractometer. The IR spectra were collected from KBr pellets on a PerkinElmer Spectrum One FT-IR spectrometer in the range of 4000-400 cm-1. The thermogravimetry and thermogravimetry mass spectrometric diagrams were collected during 30-1000 °C on a Netzsch STA 449C instrument, which is equipped with mass spectrometry Blazers MID for the thermogravimetry-mass spectrometric analyses. The emission and excitation spectra were collected using a Fluorolog-3 spectrophotometer from Horiba Jobin Yvon. The overall quantum yields were measured based on the previously reported technique, and the lifetimes were obtained on an Edinburgh FLS920 spectrofluorometer in the solid state. The diffuse reflectance spectra were recorded on an integrating sphere equipped Lambda-900 spectrophotometer from PerkinElmer company, with BaSO4 used as a reference.

Syntheses of [Ln(L1)0.5(H2O)2]⋅2H2O (Ln3+ = Eu3+, Tb3+, Gd3+) Complexes

A mixture of H6L1 (0.1 mmol) and Ln(CH3COO)3⋅8H2O (0.1 mmol) was put in a 15 mL vial followed by the addition of DMF (2 mL) and H2O (6 mL). The conc. H2SO4 (0.10 mL) was added at last. The mixture was sonicated for 10 min until heated at 85 °C. After 96 h, the colorless plate-shaped crystals formed and can be obtained by filtration.

The Mo Kα radiation equipped Rigaku Mecury CCD diffractometer was used to determine the structures of complexes 1–3 at 298 K. Data collection and reduction were finished with CrystalClear and corrected for the absorption effect with the multiscan technique SADABS, while the Supernova diffractometer of Agilent Technologies with Cu Kα radiation was employed to determine the structures of complexes 4–6 at 173 K. Data collection and reduction were analyzed using CrysAlis Pro and corrected for absorption effects using spherical harmonics, implemented in the SCALE3 ABSPACK scaling algorithm. The structures of complexes 1–6 were resolved by the direct method. And the full-matrix least-squares refinement on F 2 was finished using SHELX-97. Anisotropic refinement were applied to nonhydrogen atoms, except some disordered water molecules. Hydrogen atoms from aromatic carbon atoms were generated geometrically, while those on the water molecules were added according to the different density maps. It should be noted that the PLATON/SQUEEZE were used to obtain a series of nonsolvent diffraction of complexes 4–6, due to the highly disordered solvent molecules (counterions, water, and DMF), which could not be modeled properly. The CCDC numbers are 958048–958053 (1–6). The information of complexes 1–6 on structure refinements, selected bond lengths, and angles are given in Tables S1 and S2 of the , respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Determination

The Mo Kα radiation equipped Rigaku Mecury CCD diffractometer was used to determine the structures of complexes 1-3 at 298 K. Data collection and reduction were finished with CrystalClear and corrected for the absorption effect with the multiscan technique SADABS, while the Supernova diffractometer of Agilent Technologies with Cu Kα radiation was employed to determine the structures of complexes 4-6 at 173 K. Data collection and reduction were analyzed using CrysAlis Pro and corrected for absorption effects using spherical harmonics, implemented in the SCALE3 ABSPACK scaling algorithm. The structures of complexes 1-6 were resolved by the direct method. And the full-matrix least-squares refinement on F 2 was finished using SHELX-97. Anisotropic refinement were applied to nonhydrogen atoms, except some disordered water molecules. Hydrogen atoms from aromatic carbon atoms were generated geometrically, while those on the water molecules were added according to the different density maps. It should be noted that the PLATON/SQUEEZE were used to obtain a series of nonsolvent diffraction of complexes 4-6, due to the highly disordered solvent molecules (counterions, water, and DMF), which could not be modeled properly. The CCDC numbers are 958048-958053 (1-6). The information of complexes 1-6 on structure refinements, selected bond lengths, and angles are given in Tables S1 and S2 of the , respectively.

elements.content: Complex 1 is discussed in detail as a representative because the structures of complexes 1–3 are isomorphous to each other according to the X-ray diffraction analyses. Complex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic system P21/c space group with a europium center, half a completely deprotonated [L1]6– ligand, two coordinated water molecules, and two lattice water molecules residing in the asymmetry unit. As shown in Figure , the environment of the coordination sphere of the europium ion features a distorted capped square antiprism consisting of four oxygen atoms of chelating monodentate carboxylic groups, three oxygen atoms of μ2-bridging carboxylic groups, and two oxygen atoms of water. The bond lengths of Eu–O are comparable to the published ones, varying between 2.309(4) and 2.631(5) Å. Eu1 and the symmetry formed Eu3+ ion are connected by two chelating and bridging bidentate carboxylic groups from two independent [L1]6– ligands to generate a binuclear unit, which are then linked by syn–anti μ2-bridging bidentate carboxylic groups to give {Eu2(μ2-COO)4(COO)2} n chains, within which the separation of two adjacent Eu3+ ions are 4.316 and 5.412 Å, as shown in Figure a. The μ8-bridging ligand [L1]6– locates on an inversion center with six carboxylic groups exhibiting three kinds of coordination modes: chelating monodentate, μ2-chelating-bridging bidentate, and syn–anti μ2-bridging bidentate (Figure S1, panels a–c, of the ). The three-dimensional structure is finally constructed by connecting the adjacent four {Eu2(μ2-COO)4(COO)2} n chains through the μ8-bridging [L1]6– ligand, as shown in Figure b. The lattice water stabilizes the structure in the form of O–H···O hydrogen-bonding interactions.
elements.clean_text:
Discussion

Crystal Structure of [Ln(L1)0.5(H2O)2]⋅2H2O [Ln = Eu3+ (1), Tb3+ (2), Gd3+ (3)] Complexes

Complex 1 is discussed in detail as a representative because the structures of complexes 1-3 are isomorphous to each other according to the X-ray diffraction analyses. Complex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic system P21/c space group with a europium center, half a completely deprotonated [L1]6- ligand, two coordinated water molecules, and two lattice water molecules residing in the asymmetry unit. As shown in Figure , the environment of the coordination sphere of the europium ion features a distorted capped square antiprism consisting of four oxygen atoms of chelating monodentate carboxylic groups, three oxygen atoms of μ2-bridging carboxylic groups, and two oxygen atoms of water. The bond lengths of Eu-O are comparable to the published ones, varying between 2.309(4) and 2.631(5) Å. Eu1 and the symmetry formed Eu3+ ion are connected by two chelating and bridging bidentate carboxylic groups from two independent [L1]6- ligands to generate a binuclear unit, which are then linked by syn-anti μ2-bridging bidentate carboxylic groups to give {Eu2(μ2-COO)4(COO)2} n  chains, within which the separation of two adjacent Eu3+ ions are 4.316 and 5.412 Å, as shown in Figure a. The μ8-bridging ligand [L1]6- locates on an inversion center with six carboxylic groups exhibiting three kinds of coordination modes: chelating monodentate, μ2-chelating-bridging bidentate, and syn-anti μ2-bridging bidentate (Figure S1, panels a-c, of the ). The three-dimensional structure is finally constructed by connecting the adjacent four {Eu2(μ2-COO)4(COO)2} n  chains through the μ8-bridging [L1]6- ligand, as shown in Figure b. The lattice water stabilizes the structure in the form of O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen-bonding interactions.

elements.content: The crystal structures of complexes 4–6 are isomorphous to each other determined by the single-crystal X-ray diffraction, so the structure of 4 is analyzed in detail. In accordance with the structure analysis, complex 4 crystallizes in a triclinic system P1̅ space group and bears a 2D anionic network. This framework is balanced by one Me2NH2 + counterion which is generated in situ by a decarbonylation reaction of DMF. In the asymmetry unit of 4, there are one crystallographically unique europium center, two independent halves of incompletely deprotonated [H2L2]4– ligands, four coordinated water molecules, one Me2NH2 + cation, three lattice water molecules, and half a DMF molecule. The coordination configuration of Eu3+ ion is featured by a distorted triangular dodecahedron consisting of two chelating monodentate carboxylate oxygen atoms, two monodentate carboxylate oxygen atoms, and four terminal water molecules, as displayed in Figure . The bond length of Eu–O is in accordance with those reported, changing at 2.342(3)–2.523(3) Å. There are two kinds of connecting ligands [H2L2]4– located on inversion centers: μ3-bridging and μ2-bridging. The μ3-bridging ligands connect the adjacent Eu3+ ions with three monodentate carboxylic groups (Figure S1d of the ), generating a 1D chain substructure (Figure a). And the neighboring chains are linked through the μ2-bridging ligands using two chelating monodentate carboxylic groups generating a two-dimensional anionic network (Figure b), which further piles up to form a three-dimensional structure supported by O–H···O hydrogen bonds. The distances of the hydrogen bonds comprising O2–H2···O6D and O11–H11···O8E, which are formed between the deprotonated carboxylic group and the uncoordinated (O6D) or coordinated (O8E) carboxylate oxygen atoms in each two-dimensional anionic network as shown in Figure , are 2.570 and 2.574 Å (symmetry codes: D, 2 – x, −y, 1 – z and E, −x, −y, 2 – z).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of [Me2NH2][Ln(H2L2)(H2O)4]⋅0.5DMF⋅xH2O [Ln = Eu3+ (4), Tb3+ (5), Gd3+ (6)] Complexes

The crystal structures of complexes 4-6 are isomorphous to each other determined by the single-crystal X-ray diffraction, so the structure of 4 is analyzed in detail. In accordance with the structure analysis, complex 4 crystallizes in a triclinic system P1̅ space group and bears a 2D anionic network. This framework is balanced by one Me2NH2 + counterion which is generated in situ by a decarbonylation reaction of DMF. In the asymmetry unit of 4, there are one crystallographically unique europium center, two independent halves of incompletely deprotonated [H2L2]4- ligands, four coordinated water molecules, one Me2NH2 + cation, three lattice water molecules, and half a DMF molecule. The coordination configuration of Eu3+ ion is featured by a distorted triangular dodecahedron consisting of two chelating monodentate carboxylate oxygen atoms, two monodentate carboxylate oxygen atoms, and four terminal water molecules, as displayed in Figure . The bond length of Eu-O is in accordance with those reported, changing at 2.342(3)-2.523(3) Å. There are two kinds of connecting ligands [H2L2]4- located on inversion centers: μ3-bridging and μ2-bridging. The μ3-bridging ligands connect the adjacent Eu3+ ions with three monodentate carboxylic groups (Figure S1d of the ), generating a 1D chain substructure (Figure a). And the neighboring chains are linked through the μ2-bridging ligands using two chelating monodentate carboxylic groups generating a two-dimensional anionic network (Figure b), which further piles up to form a three-dimensional structure supported by O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds. The distances of the hydrogen bonds comprising O2-H2⋅⋅⋅O6D and O11-H11⋅⋅⋅O8E, which are formed between the deprotonated carboxylic group and the uncoordinated (O6D) or coordinated (O8E) carboxylate oxygen atoms in each two-dimensional anionic network as shown in Figure , are 2.570 and 2.574 Å (symmetry codes: D, 2 - x, -y, 1 - z and E, -x, -y, 2 - z).

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analyses of complexes 1–6 are displayed in Figure S2 of the . The detailed discussion of thermal stability for complexes 1 and 4 is chosen as representative. In complex 1, 15.34% weight loss is found during 30–198 °C matching with the departure of two lattices and two coordinated waters (theoretical, 15.39%). There is no weight loss until 400 °C, when the residual occurs to collapse. In complex 4, the gradual departure of three lattice water molecules is found with 6.44% weight loss between 30 and 125 °C, followed by a 4.27% mass loss of half a DMF molecule in the lattice by the end of 277 °C (theoretical, 4.29%), after which the residual begins to decompose. The aforementioned analysis of complex 4 is consistent with the TG-MS result, as shown in Figure S3 of the .
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Stability and Powder X-ray Diffraction

Thermogravimetric analyses of complexes 1-6 are displayed in Figure S2 of the . The detailed discussion of thermal stability for complexes 1 and 4 is chosen as representative. In complex 1, 15.34% weight loss is found during 30-198 °C matching with the departure of two lattices and two coordinated waters (theoretical, 15.39%). There is no weight loss until 400 °C, when the residual occurs to collapse. In complex 4, the gradual departure of three lattice water molecules is found with 6.44% weight loss between 30 and 125 °C, followed by a 4.27% mass loss of half a DMF molecule in the lattice by the end of 277 °C (theoretical, 4.29%), after which the residual begins to decompose. The aforementioned analysis of complex 4 is consistent with the TG-MS result, as shown in Figure S3 of the .

elements.content: The powder X-ray diffraction was used to examine the purities of the crystalline samples 1–6. The diffraction patterns (Figure S4 of the ) are in accordance with the simulated ones, supporting phase purity of the complexes.

elements.content: The UV–Vis diffuse reflectance spectra of complexes 1–6 and the free ligands are displayed in Figure S5 of the . The free ligands H6L1 and H6L2 exhibit the absorption that is assigned to electronic transitions of n → π* or π → π*. And the complexation with lanthanide does not have a significant influence on the singlet excited states of the ligands, which can be supported by the absorption behaviors of the complexes that behave in a similar way as the free ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Electronic State of the Ligands

The UV-Vis diffuse reflectance spectra of complexes 1-6 and the free ligands are displayed in Figure S5 of the . The free ligands H6L1 and H6L2 exhibit the absorption that is assigned to electronic transitions of n → π* or π → π*. And the complexation with lanthanide does not have a significant influence on the singlet excited states of the ligands, which can be supported by the absorption behaviors of the complexes that behave in a similar way as the free ligands.

elements.content: The energy migration process of lanthanide coordination polymer is usually considered as ligand absorption followed by intersystem crossing (1S* → 3T*), energy transfer (3T* → Ln*), and luminescence of lanthanide (Ln*). Therefore, optical sensitized ligand should possess a triplet state that situates sufficiently above the 5D0 emitting level (17500 cm–1) of Eu3+ or 5D4 level (20500 cm–1) of Tb3+ to make the energy transfer process more efficient. Furthermore, the energy gap between the triplet state of the ligand and the emissive level of lanthanide is often associated with the energy transfer efficiency. Thus, the determination of the triplet state energy is necessary for a coordinated ligand. In this work, the triplet state energies of the ligands have been estimated through the lower emission edges of the 77 K phosphorescence spectra by their corresponding Gd3+ complexes (3 and 6) (Figure S6 of the ), since the energy of the 6P7/2 level is too high to be populated by the majority of sensitized ligands. And the calculated energies of the ligands’ triplet states turn out to be 24000 cm–1 (416 nm, H6L1) and 21200 cm–1 (472 nm, H6L2), lying about 300–6000 cm–1 above the 5D0 (Eu3+) and 5D4 (Tb3+) emitting levels, which can sensitize the Eu3+ or Tb3+ luminescence.

elements.content: Figure displays the combination of excitation and emission spectra of Eu3+ and Tb3+ complexes. The excitation spectra were obtained by monitoring the strongest emissions of Eu3+ (617 nm) and Tb3+ (544 nm) in the solid state. And they display prominent ligand bands between 250 and 400 nm, therefore, confirming the existence of the ligand sensitizing process. Meanwhile, some characteristic emissions of the europium energy level resulting from the transitions between the 7F0,1 and 5G6, 5H4, 5L6, and 5D3, 2, 1 levels are also observed in complexes 1 and 4. With regard to Tb3+ complexes 2 and 5, weak lines characteristic of terbium energy levels are also detected, which can be assigned to transitions between the 7F5 and 5L10 and 5G6 levels.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Properties of Eu3+ and Tb3+ Complexes

Figure  displays the combination of excitation and emission spectra of Eu3+ and Tb3+ complexes. The excitation spectra were obtained by monitoring the strongest emissions of Eu3+ (617 nm) and Tb3+ (544 nm) in the solid state. And they display prominent ligand bands between 250 and 400 nm, therefore, confirming the existence of the ligand sensitizing process. Meanwhile, some characteristic emissions of the europium energy level resulting from the transitions between the 7F0,1 and 5G6, 5H4, 5L6, and 5D3, 2, 1 levels are also observed in complexes 1 and 4. With regard to Tb3+ complexes 2 and 5, weak lines characteristic of terbium energy levels are also detected, which can be assigned to transitions between the 7F5 and 5L10 and 5G6 levels.

elements.content: Excitation of the Eu3+ and Tb3+ complexes in the solid state (354 nm for 1 and 2 and 348 nm for 4 and 5) at room temperature results in the observation of the characteristic red and green luminescence, arising from 5D0 → 7FJ (J = 0–4) for Eu3+ and 5D4 → 7FJ (J = 6–3) for Tb3+, respectively (Figure ). The characteristic emissions of 5D0 → 7F2 and 5D4 → 7F5 dominate the whole emission spectra of the Eu3+ and Tb3+ luminescence. However, the weak ligand-centered emissions are detected in the range of 400–450 nm, confirming the inefficient ligand sensitizing energy transfer process.
elements.clean_text: Excitation of the Eu3+ and Tb3+ complexes in the solid state (354 nm for 1 and 2 and 348 nm for 4 and 5) at room temperature results in the observation of the characteristic red and green luminescence, arising from 5D0 → 7FJ (J = 0-4) for Eu3+ and 5D4 → 7FJ (J = 6-3) for Tb3+, respectively (Figure ). The characteristic emissions of 5D0 → 7F2 and 5D4 → 7F5 dominate the whole emission spectra of the Eu3+ and Tb3+ luminescence. However, the weak ligand-centered emissions are detected in the range of 400-450 nm, confirming the inefficient ligand sensitizing energy transfer process.

elements.content: Combination of the excitation spectra and emission spectra of Eu3+ and Tb3+ complexes. The excitation spectra were recorded by monitoring the 5D0 → 7F2 (617 nm) transition of Eu3+ ion and the 5D4→7F5 transition (544 nm) of Tb3+ ion, and the emission spectra were recorded by excitation via the ligand-centered electronic transitions of the Eu3+ and Tb3+ complexes (354 nm for 1 and 2 and 348 nm for 4 and 5).
elements.clean_text: 8  Combination of the excitation spectra and emission spectra of Eu3+ and Tb3+ complexes. The excitation spectra were recorded by monitoring the 5D0 → 7F2 (617 nm) transition of Eu3+ ion and the 5D4→7F5 transition (544 nm) of Tb3+ ion, and the emission spectra were recorded by excitation via the ligand-centered electronic transitions of the Eu3+ and Tb3+ complexes (354 nm for 1 and 2 and 348 nm for 4 and 5).

elements.content: The emission lifetimes of 5D4 → 7F2 (Eu3+) and 5D0 → 7F5 (Tb3+) are determined under the excitation of ligand-centered transitions in the solid state. The observed luminescence decays are well-fitted to single exponential functions at 298 K and 77 K that are in agreement with one emissive lanthanide ion in the crystal structures. The luminescence decay curves for all complexes as well as the fitting results are shown in Figure S7 of the , and the data of the lifetimes are listed in Table . Upon cooling from 298 to 77 K, the slight variations of the lifetime in complexes 1, 2, and 4 point to the absence of significant thermally activated deactivation processes, such as energy back transfer, ligand-to-metal charge transfer, other intermolecular interactions, and so on, while the large variation of lifetime in complex 5 is probably due to the existence of the back-energy transfer process.

elements.content: The overall quantum yields of lanthanide complexes mainly depend on two factors: the energy transfer process and the nonradiative deactivation process. The Φoverall in [L1]6– containing Eu3+ complex (1) amounts to 11%, smaller than 32% in Tb3+ complex (2). Such observation can be explained by the efficient energy transfer between the sensitized ligand and lanthanide center, which is correlated with the energy gap of the ligand’s triplet state (3ππ*) and the Ln3+ ion’s emission level. In accordance with the empirical rule of Latva et al., an optical energy transfer process for Eu3+ needs ΔE(3ππ*-5D0) = 2500–4000 cm–1 and for Tb3+, ΔE(3ππ*-5D4) = 2500–4500 cm–1. The calculated ΔE is 6500 cm–1 for 1 and 3500 cm–1 for 2, which is optimum to sensitize the Tb3+ (5D4) emission. Therefore, significant larger quantum yield has been observed in the Tb3+ complex (2).
elements.clean_text: The overall quantum yields of lanthanide complexes mainly depend on two factors: the energy transfer process and the nonradiative deactivation process. The Φoverall in [L1]6- containing Eu3+ complex (1) amounts to 11%, smaller than 32% in Tb3+ complex (2). Such observation can be explained by the efficient energy transfer between the sensitized ligand and lanthanide center, which is correlated with the energy gap of the ligand's triplet state (3ππ*) and the Ln3+ ion's emission level. In accordance with the empirical rule of Latva et al., an optical energy transfer process for Eu3+ needs ΔE(3ππ*-5D0) = 2500-4000 cm-1 and for Tb3+, ΔE(3ππ*-5D4) = 2500-4500 cm-1. The calculated ΔE is 6500 cm-1 for 1 and 3500 cm-1 for 2, which is optimum to sensitize the Tb3+ (5D4) emission. Therefore, significant larger quantum yield has been observed in the Tb3+ complex (2).

elements.content: This situation is different for [H2L2]4– containing complexes owing to the predominant high-vibrational OH-inducing nonradiative deactivation process. Despite the better energy transfer efficiency of 4, the nonradiative rate constant increases by 0.5-fold compared to 1, leading to the reduction of the overall quantum yield. Furthermore, the Φoverall for the Eu3+ complex (4) is 7%, while it amounts to 25% for the Tb3+ complex (5) even with the small energy gap [ΔE(3ππ*-5D4) = 700 cm–1]. This is probably because the deactivation process caused by coordinated water is less favorable for Tb3+ complexes compared to Eu3+ complexes since the energy gaps between the emissive levels and the ground levels are smaller for Eu3+ (5D0-7F6 gap:12300 cm–1) than for Tb3+ (5D4-7F0 gap: 14700 cm–1), which leads to the more favorable coupling with the third vibrational overtone of the proximate OH oscillators (νOH ∼ 3300–3500 cm–1) for the excited states of europium ion. It is also supported by the phenomenon that the lifetimes of all the Eu3+ complexes (1 and 4) are a little shorter than those of the corresponding Tb3+ complexes (2 and 5).

Despite the better energy transfer efficiency of 4, the nonradiative rate constant increases by 0.5-fold compared to 1, leading to the reduction of the overall quantum yield. Furthermore, the Φoverall for the Eu3+ complex (4) is 7%, while it amounts to 25% for the Tb3+ complex (5) even with the small energy gap [ΔE(3ππ*-5D4) = 700 cm-1]. This is probably because the deactivation process caused by coordinated water is less favorable for Tb3+ complexes compared to Eu3+ complexes since the energy gaps between the emissive levels and the ground levels are smaller for Eu3+ (5D0-7F6 gap:12300 cm-1) than for Tb3+ (5D4-7F0 gap: 14700 cm-1), which leads to the more favorable coupling with the third vibrational overtone of the proximate OH oscillators (νOH ~ 3300-3500 cm-1) for the excited states of europium ion. It is also supported by the phenomenon that the lifetimes of all the Eu3+ complexes (1 and 4) are a little shorter than those of the corresponding Tb3+ complexes (2 and 5).

elements.content: Furthermore, due to the nonradiative deactivation process caused by the inner sphere water molecules, the lifetimes for complexes 4 and 5 are shorter compared to 1 and 2. Actually, with respect to complexes 4, the calculated nonradiative rate constant of 1 decreases by about 30% that can be ascribed to two water molecules, compared to the four existing in the coordination sphere of the europium center. These data emphasize the significant impact of the triple state energy of ligands and coordinated water in the inner sphere on luminescent properties. For the purpose of getting the lanthanide complexes with excellent luminescent properties, using ligands with matched triplet energy level and removing water from the coordination sphere are required.

elements.content: We have solvothermally synthesized six new lanthanide coordination polymers, with the structures and optical properties being studied. Complexes 1–3 show 3D framework architecture with 6-connected (412.63) topology, and complexes 4–6 exhibit a 2D structure with simplified (3,4)-connected bimodal (4.62)(42.62.82) net. The triplet state energies of the ligands H6L1 and H6L2 lie in a desired position to sensitize the Tb3+ or Eu3+ luminescence, rendering the characteristic red emission of Eu3+ due to 5D0→7FJ (J = 0–4) transitions or green emission of Tb3+ due to 5D4→7FJ (J = 6–3) transitions, respectively. The photophysical parameters emphasize the significant impact of the triple state energy of ligands and water molecules in the coordination sphere on optical properties of lanthanide coordination polymers. The good match of the energy between the triplet state of the ligand and the emissive level of the lanthanide ion makes the energy transfer more efficient and thus the larger overall quantum yield. Furthermore, the nonradiative deactivation process caused by the inner-sphere coordination water molecules has a significant negative influence on the overall quantum yield and lifetimes, especially for the Eu3+ ion which is more likely quenched by OH oscillators compared to Tb3+ ion.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

We have solvothermally synthesized six new lanthanide coordination polymers, with the structures and optical properties being studied. Complexes 1-3 show 3D framework architecture with 6-connected (412.63) topology, and complexes 4-6 exhibit a 2D structure with simplified (3,4)-connected bimodal (4.62)(42.62.82) net. The triplet state energies of the ligands H6L1 and H6L2 lie in a desired position to sensitize the Tb3+ or Eu3+ luminescence, rendering the characteristic red emission of Eu3+ due to 5D0→7FJ (J = 0-4) transitions or green emission of Tb3+ due to 5D4→7FJ (J = 6-3) transitions, respectively. The photophysical parameters emphasize the significant impact of the triple state energy of ligands and water molecules in the coordination sphere on optical properties of lanthanide coordination polymers. The good match of the energy between the triplet state of the ligand and the emissive level of the lanthanide ion makes the energy transfer more efficient and thus the larger overall quantum yield. Furthermore, the nonradiative deactivation process caused by the inner-sphere coordination water molecules has a significant negative influence on the overall quantum yield and lifetimes, especially for the Eu3+ ion which is more likely quenched by OH oscillators compared to Tb3+ ion.

A mixture of H6L1 (0.1 mmol) and Ln(CH3COO)3·8H2O (0.1 mmol) was put in a 15 mL vial followed by the addition of DMF (2 mL) and H2O (6 mL). The conc. H2SO4 (0.10 mL) was added at last. The mixture was sonicated for 10 min until heated at 85 °C. After 96 h, the colorless plate-shaped crystals formed and can be obtained by filtration.

IR (KBr, cm–1): 3420 (s), 2810 (w), 1665 (s), 1609 (s), 1557 (s), 1443 (s), 1398 (s), 1346(w), 1106 (w), 1082 (w), 1021 (w), 835 (w), 790(w), 763 (w). (Yield: ca. 58% based on Gd.)

Thermal Stability and Powder X-ray Diffraction

Thermogravimetric analyses of complexes 1–6 are displayed in Figure S2 of the . The detailed discussion of thermal stability for complexes 1 and 4 is chosen as representative. In complex 1, 15.34% weight loss is found during 30–198 °C matching with the departure of two lattices and two coordinated waters (theoretical, 15.39%). There is no weight loss until 400 °C, when the residual occurs to collapse. In complex 4, the gradual departure of three lattice water molecules is found with 6.44% weight loss between 30 and 125 °C, followed by a 4.27% mass loss of half a DMF molecule in the lattice by the end of 277 °C (theoretical, 4.29%), after which the residual begins to decompose. The aforementioned analysis of complex 4 is consistent with the TG-MS result, as shown in Figure S3 of the .
